A lot of movies get an R rating for "sex", which can mean a couple of moments of nudity, or "language", which can mean "the way the angry striking workers shown in this documentary talk".  My children, too, have seen plenty of R rated movies. 'The King's Speech" is rated R -- my kids have seen it twice, and I am quite pleased that they liked it enough to want to. You really have to take it case-by-case. There are a lot of movies with PG-13 movies that I would NOT want them to see. I do not want them to see movies with ongoing, graphic, mindless violence -- a lot of those movies are rated PG-13. I do not want them to see frat boys getting drunk and hitting on drunken girls dancing on top of tables in flimsy t-shirts. A lot of those movies are rated PG-13.

My husband's childhood priest told of a little boy who corresponds with his grandmother after she gave him a sweater, saying, "Dear Grandma, Thanks for the sweater. It's just what I always wanted, only not very much." Mia should write this to her grandma, if her parents (especially her father) won't communicate this to Grandma themselves. She could enclose it with the gifted items; returning them to Grandma for her regifting/refunding would be honest, empowering and clear. Just because a gift is given does not mean it has to be accepted.

Grandma's intent is unknown here. However, the above thank you note could start a frank conversation which should include the question to Grandma of what IS her motive in these gifts? Is it to please Mia? If so, she's way off the mark and knowing it should help her. Informing her of the things that please Mia as she grows would enable Grandma to achieve this goal. Additionally, without clarifying for Grandma what makes Mia truly happy, Mia must feel like she didn't really get a gift.

Perhaps Grandma's gifts have nothing to do with Mia and everything to do with Grandma - comparing her gifts to those which her contemporaries buy for their grandchildren, reenacting her own childhood (either what she had and enjoyed, or what she didn't have and missed), or perhaps transgender really is an issue in this family which Grandma is trying to either ignore or bully Mia out of (good luck with that).

Speaking the truth in love serves all.

Thank you so very much Ms. Sheer. Ms. Bates, in my humble opinion, was a great American. She saw and felt the greatness of this country without closing her eyes to the traits and actions that took away from our greatness. She accentuates the positive without ignoring our shortcomings and imperfections. Her words make me proud to have been born in this nation while giving me more strength to continue to work for the things that we must correct about our lack of control and selfishness.

Again, thank you for reminding us in the most positive way about unconditional love for our country without failing to recognize that its greatness carries temptations that have and will be abused to the detriment of its beauty and meaning.

I wish that would be elected officials of all colors, creeds and persuasions along with MSNBC, Fox News and the like stop talking past the substance of what Ms. Bates wrote and what you have been so good at reminding us. This is part of civic engagement in a democracy that all too often commits acts of ignorance as wrapping ones self in the image of the American flag while talking about why one group is more American than the other. We all seem to be struggling to be a "good American" but your contribution with this column helped me right my ship.

STAY THE COURSE:
It's a nautical term, referring to the use of "stays" (ropes, basically) to support the mainsail (the "course'.) Its ubiquitous present misuse as the equivalent of "stick it out to the end" can probably be attributed to our former President GW Malaprop.

Uh, maybe other people value their quality of life in other ways. Maybe they're avoiding that suburban subdivision because they don't want to spend hours a week in their car instead of with their kids, walking around the neighborhood, or doing errands that require nothing more than putting the kids in the stroller and walking out the door.

In fact, I might even argue that the parent that structures their life so that they have the most time with their kids (driving a 2 year old in the car is not spending time with them), even when performing mundane tasks, is a better parent. So where does that leave the sanctimonious parent who insists that they must be a better parent because they bought the house that requires a 30-60 minute commute each way to work/daycare--time not spent with their children?

champion88: I don't get your point.  Casting aspersions has no bearing upon the necessity of locking some people up. On the other hand, should homosexuality be criminalized?  Even at the level of the (alleged) nexus between religious and secular affairs, our system of laws is taken primarily from the ten commandments.  I don't recall homosexuality (let alone homosexual marriage) being covered there, or did Moses just neglect to bring one of those tablets down with him from Sinai?  People should be incarcerated when they harm other people.  Gay marriage harms no one.  Nor does it invalidate heterosexual marriage.  Okay?

Dear Sen. Santorum (also Gov. Romney, Rep. Gingrich, Gov. Perry and that crazy lady who recently bowed out),
Please stop mistating/misinterpreting everything I've said and done in order to validate your own prejudices. At no time have I condemned homosexuals (who are my children no less than you) nor have I expressed any feelings one way or another re: their right to marry, adopt, serve in the military or educate your children. I do, however, condone my son's injunction to the effect that only those who are themselves without sin be permitted to cast aspersions at other sinners. Last I looked, Rick/Willard/Newt/Jim/Crazy Lady, each of you owned a record of personal failings for which a good deal of time will need to be expended in pleading for forgiveness on my part. I would honestly suggest that you all start right now and stop wasting that time telling homosexuals (and blacks and women and Muslims) how superior you are to them with regards to your own personal morality. I would, in fact, recommend that you leave such matters as the punishment of sin in the hands of yours truly and figure out instead how you're going to balance the budget without raising the taxes of the "job creators" (and I use that term euphemistically) whose donations have been keeping your respective presidential campaigns afloat. That would, of course, require a miracle, but I'm afraid I'm not of a mind to help you with that one.
Yours truly,
Allah
(Just funning with you, Rick)

There's a Hypothetical Scenario C that wasn't explored in this article.  In Scenario C, Perry's strategists informed him that he couldn't win the nomination.  However, Perry had long-term strategic interests for remaining in the race.  For example, he could be considering a 2014 run, or maybe he wants to have a talk show.  For these long-term goals, staying in the race (and the public eye) longer would be in Perry's strategic interest - even if he has no shot of winning the primary.

A good leader when to lead from the front, when to step aside, and when to step behind. For those who are accustomed to leaders give speeches and direct/dictate, the idea of "crowd sourcing" may seem odd.
Corruption is endemic to Indian society. It has been there for centuries, whether leaders were Maharajas, colonial rulers or democratically elected leaders. The notion of giving "bakshish" to get something done is now woven in Indian culture.
If we are to change this weave, then we will have to get the citizens involved. It will be a long and hard process. There will be some missteps along the way.
There is no fool-proof plan when it comes to social change. By asking followers for the future direction is a way to keep the conversation on corruption going. That is the first step.
The solutions will have to vary from state to state because the regional cultures are so different. The central unifying concept will have to be the accountability of the elected and appointed officials, without exception.

Corruption in India: Have you no shame?
